Fascinating!!! I have known about the Prince Rupert’s drop for some time but never seen such a great presentation of the phenomenon.
Prince Rupert’s life is equally fascinating. He was the child of the last elected Bohemian king (who was actually German). Rupert was born in Prague and was almost left behind when the king and queen Elisabeth of Bohemia (sister of king Charles II) were fleeing Bohemia after protestants lost the Battle of White Mountain near Prague in 1620. Rupert spent some time at the English court, and was a privateer financing the royalists during the time of English civil war. We was a POW held in Linz, Austria, where he supposedly discovered the properties of the drop. After returning to England when king Charles was reinstated, he became the first governor of the Hudson Bay Company which operates in Canada until today and is the oldest incorporated company in North America. The “Rupert’s Land” was roughly what today are the provinces of Quebec, Ontario & maritimes, and eventually became Canada.
The town of Prince Rupert in British Columbia is named after him.
There you go. A fascinating history of a fascinating phenomenon discovered by a man with fascinating life.

When I was a kid in the 60s, we had s subscription to a kids scientific book series. They came with a bunch of glossy color stickers that you would lick and put in the books in the proper places. In my day, that was called "entertainment." For a little kid it was a fun activity.
One thing I remember to this day was a chapter on Prince Rupert's Drops. There was a pic of him standing in a noble pose, one hand on his hip, the other extended pouring the molten glass into a bucket of water.
I wish I could remember the name of the series. They came in a slip container with a few volumes in each. They were simply constructed, just stapled together with the sticker bound in the middle. I can still remember looking at the collection many times and trying to choose which one to read.

Just a thing, 1 mile per second is 3600mph which is Mach 4.5! 4.5x the speed of sound, is how fast the failure front travels! No wonder it explodes.

Of course that's 4.5x the speed of sound in air. In air that's 330 m/2. In glass the speed of sound is 3280 m/s, so the failure front is about half the speed of sound in glass. It's still very fast.

🧐🧐🧐🤔🤔Looks to me like the outside of the glass “the shell” is holding all the energy within the drop and the internal explosion only happens when the energy has no where else to expand. Then the energy explodes the outer shell. Since the energy is able to expand down the long tail as fast as the vibration (heat wave?) can move down the shell which is over 100,000 frames per second, the energy hits the end of the expansion, swells, and explodes the glass. Kinda the same principle as squirting a regular water hose where the outside tension strength hold the stream until it can expand at a certain distance due the the stretching of the water and the power behind the stream.  I wonder how long the tail can get and this still works? It seems indefinitely until the power of the energy slows due to expansion?. Prince Rupert of the Rhine lived most of his life in England. He was the son of The Elector Palatine of the Rhine and a sister of Charles I of England. As a young man he was exiled from his patrimony after his father made a failed attempt to become King of Bohemia, and became a 'Protestant Martyr' in the process. As a nephew of Charles I, he settled in England and served as a leading Royalist general in the English Civil War, he was especially noted as a cavalry leader. He later served as an admiral under his cousin Charles II. Like Charles II, he was very interested in science.

It's the water that causes the reaction. Water cannot go higher than 212.
When the molten glass drops into the water, the heat of the glass cannot be absorbed by the water (can't go over 212)... the heat is forced out the tail... this creates a "phase shift" of heat energy to pressure and sound to get the "heat energy" out as quickly as possible. The point in the tail... is the phase shifting point. When the glass cools that point is sealed. There is a lack of pressure through the "sound harmonics" of energy. Glass is special in that it will reflect anything not on the other side. The Rupert's Drop having phase shifted the heat to pressure and sound, has drastically less than on the outside. The "magic glass" reflects the pressure through the sound harmonic. If you strike the Rupert's Drop hard enough to make a spark (a phase shift of pressure to light to expend excess kinetic energy)... it will pop the rupert's drop. If you "unseal" the Phase Shifting point, it will shatter.
Now, if I could just make one... but that's what happens. Magic Energy Reflecting Glass... dropped in Magic Temperature Restrictive Water causes a phase shift of heat to sound and pressure. Something like that is likely how the Mayans made the stones for their walls, as well.
Evolution is impossible... by the way. :)

Optimizing Prince Rupert's Drop:

1. Construct cylinder for molten drop to free fall into until fully solidified.
a. The diameter of this cylinder should be slightly double that of the maximum range diameter of the solidified drop.
b. Thus 8 to 10 inches in diameter in order to make sure the volume within the cylinder remains efficient.
c. The height of the cylinder must be in linear proportion to the time that:
i. Gravity.
ii. Heat of molten drop.
iii. Solidification time for acquiring solidified drop.
in order for the molten drop to be solidified in a constant free-fall state for optimal molecular structure solidification.
2. Fill chamber with a highly purified cooling agent.
a. Cooling agent can have high or low friction frequencies upon molten drop.
i. High friction frequency incurs shorter free-fall distance.
ii. Low friction frequency incurs longer free-fall distance.
b. Cooling agent should be highly purified.
i. low purification incurs increased variations in molecular solidification structure process.
ii. high purification incurs decreased variations in molecular solidification structure process.
c. Temperature of cooling agent should be very low.
i. If cooling agent is too hot, the molecular solidification process will have to travel through to much time and space
ii. If cooling agent is very cold, the molecular solidification process will allow for faster atomic bonding to incur,
thus allowing for optimal atomic stacking within fused structure.
3. Limit the air-time duration from furnace to cylindrical cooling chamber.
a. Minimizing the travel time the molten drop undertakes allows the molten drop to solidify with greater time in the cooling agent.
b. The air outside the furnace instantly starts to act as a cooling agent when the molten drop leaves exits.
c. This outside air could have inconsistencies the can incur unwanted variations in the molecular solidification process.
4. Optimize the Drop Process:
a. Allow as much of the molten drops consistency to fall at the front.
i. Having too long of a tail can incur increased variations in molecular solidification.
ii. Having too long of a tail may induce unwanted curling, increasing the brittle factors of structure.
iii. Allowing the bulk of the mass of the glass at the front, will allow most of the atomic stacking to be focused on the nose cone.
b. Insure that the molten drop is done nearest to the center-point of the cylindrical cooling agent.
i. Due to the molecular stacking of the cooling agent within the cylinder:
ia. The center-point allows for equal pressure distributions, 
(according to Archimede's Principle),
upon both the object being immersed, and the fluid body within the cylinder chamber.
5. Variations in length and width of solidified Drop:
a. A shorter length, and wider width, for the solidified drop.
b. A longer length, and narrower width, for the solidified drop.
c. Each variation can have proportional advantages and disadvantages for a given durability test.
6. Have Fun!

This reminds me of how katanas are made. the sword is forged straight, and then quenched in a way that the iron on the edge cools so rapidly that the molecules rearrange so that they take up more space, while the iron molecules in the spine cools slowly because of the coating so they assume a more compact arrangement. This whole process gives the sword's edge a crystalline and brittle nature while making the spine flexible and springlike, it also gives the sword its backward curve. The whole sword is in constant tension because of the springy spine trying to straighten against the expanded edge. In this case with the glass. The outside cools more rapidly than the inside. What makes this so tough is the balance between tensive force on the inside and compressive force on the outside, when the tail breaks the balance is broken.

Safety automotive glass windows are purposely stressed like this, too.  This is to ensure that they break up into very small pieces, rather than long strong sharp shards which can easily give you terminal wounds.  People used to frequently get decapitated by windshields, going out through their head created hole, and pulling those shards back closed on the way back in...nasty.  Anyway, I was drilling a rear side window to put a hole in it with a brass tube and some valve grinding compound to mount it PERMANENTLY to the closure mechanism, because the glue was always failing after a few months to a year, and I was almost all the way through it, so I slowed down the drilling rate to come out the back side gently.  Well...it wasn't gentle enough, because it shattered, some of it ending up all the way across the garage (two car).  Also, I had a red streak across my abdomen, which obviously took up the pretty serious amount of energy stored up in that safety glass.  I was pretty amazed at how much energy there was, I would estimate quite a bit more than that drop.  It, also, sounded pretty much instantaneous as it went.  Might be interesting to high speed film one, but do it behind a safety shield.  I don't think that energy would be much of an issue with the glass breaking in the frame, because it all seemed to be longitudinal in the glass, so the frame would take most of the hit.

It is interesting that the glass seems to explode, presumably because of the propagating imbalance of broken molecular bonds (fractures) started in the very fragile tail, causing the fractures to unbalance the next molecules, like dominoes, and the outer shell of compressed glass molecules is released like BBs from a billions of microscopic slingshots. I think there is an analogy here to prestressed concrete, in which the cables apply a huge compressive residual stress, so that the only effect of what would normally be destructive tensile forces applied to the concrete, only serves to reduce the existing compression. The member is able to fail only if the tensile force is huge enough to overcome the huge residual compressive strain.
I suspect that research into the tail and where it becomes critical would reveal manufacturing options. During formation, the tail obviously fractures or breaks from the formation drip, but this structural domino chain probably only develops at some critical distance or diameter or rate of cooling or combination.
But I noticed in another video, that the tail (at least part of it) did not explode even after bouncing around on the press table (anvil), meaning that it was not part of the trigger structure (or it would have contained the 'domino chain' which would have shattered).

How is it that I'm just now finding this? Feels like I'm watching a compartmentalized atomic reaction which, only takes place in the glass. To me, this reminds me of resonant frequency response.  The hammer strike didn't set it off. Same goes with the bullet strikes. The resonant frequency of the vibration throughout the glass did.  That frequency varies depending on the length and diameter of the drop. Like playing a single string in a piano or guitar from across the room without physically touching it. ( I.e. I sing/play an E through a trumpet, the E string vibrates producing the E note of the same octave in the guitar/piano, from across the room.) Ceramic has a similar effect with glass. I don't know if the sound can be captured in a way to analyze juxtaposed to the high speed footage. I would imagine that the spectrum to focus on would be a (VHF) very high frequency. It would be interesting to study, though.

Great video. But at 4:33, you incorrectly state that 13,000 psi represents twice the pressure at the bottom of Mariana trench. The density of salt water is 64 pounds per cubic foot and this force is applied upon 144 square inches. (i.e pressure increase per foot of depth is 0.444 psi). Google says the Mariana trench is 36070 feet deep. Multiplying the pressure increase per foot of depth times the depth... 0.444 * 36070 = 16,015psi. In other words, you're off by a factor of roughly 2.5 (16,015/6,500 = 2.464)

Seems like an effect of surface-tension to me.  It's as if the glass is behaving like a super-cooled liquid with a surface tension strong enough to behave like a solid.  Once the surface tension is disrupted, it seems to flash-"freeze".  Glass is a crystal, just like water, it's just that at room temperature glass is in solid form and water is in liquid form.  The freezing point of glass is well above room temperature.

One thing I haven't seen discussed in videos of Prince Rupert's drops is whether the glass flows toward the tail as the drop forms. If the entire outside of a bead solidifies and cools too quickly while the inside is still hot, the glass inside will push outward until the surface cracks. Since a bead must be cooled down over a period of hours to prevent that from happening, it would seem like that would certainly happen when a bead is dropped in water unless the molten glass inside the head could flow up toward the tail before the tail hardened. Would it be possible to use a high speed with a polariscope to see how the stresses develop, or would bubbling at the surface of the water make such filming too difficult?

I was a welder. This is something you have to think about when welding, and engineers have to calculate the stresses induced by welding.
   If a weld has been done properly the welded unit never fails at the weld itself. The fracture happens NEXT to the weld, due to the stresses induced by the welding process.
  In structural welds you never let the metal cool too quickly (by quenching it) but when you're learning to welt you'll put a bunch of welds on the same piece of scrap. Quenching is common because these welds aren't going to be used for anything. I was surprised here because the glass bulb continues to glow for a lot longer than steal would. But then steel is quite a lot better at conducting heat so the heat in the steal moves into the water much more quickly than it would in glass.

I had to come back and watch this one again, seeing the break is so amazing. The speed of the failure or shock front is so impressive. 

The typical failure front in gas detonations range from 1800 m/s to 3000 m/s while typical velocities in solid explosives often range beyond 4000 m/s to more than10000 m/s. Detonation involves a supersonic exothermic front accelerating through a medium that eventually drives a shock front propagating directly in front of it. This is a mechanical release of energy not an exothermic but it fit's the other definitions of a detonation.

Couple Questions: 
Would one be incorrect in calling this a type of detonation?
Does the size of the Prince Rupert's drop affect the speed at which the failure front travels?

Fascinating physics, which I wouldn't have understood without this help, but there are faults with the history at the end. This is nothing to do with Bavaria, but Batavia, which is a historical name used for the Netherlands and things/places connected with them. Prince Rupert was a relation of Charles II's hugely interested in science, and he brought Drops over to England. (They were both involved in the founding of the Royal Society early in Charles's reign; it is still a special honour for scientists to become Fellows, be impressed by an FRS at the end of a scientist's qualifications.) However, Wikipedia suggests that the drops were first made elsewhere in northern Europe and brought to Holland, which was a very successful part of Europe at the time (and hence able to provide work for artists like Rembrandt).

I have a question, why isn't it water bursting out instead of pieces of glass ?

The Prince Rupert drop is melted glass dropped into some water to cool it. What is happening is the outer glass is being cooled instantly, on contact with the water, preventing the inner glass from being cooled as quickly. Because the outer glass cools FIRST, it causes so much outwards pressure to be cause by the inner glass cooling as it expands and solidifies. The reason you can't break the bulb by trying to actually break the bulb it's self is because with the internal pressure it has from the glass being cooled slower on the inside, it is actually harder than steel. BUT, in order to break it all you need to do is break its tail, for when you break the tail the pressure on the inside is released, causing the entire thing to explode.

so smart guy, i'm also a glassblower for 30 years  and make the PRD
 how about answering  this:
 notice that when the drop is in the water a bubble or void forms in the tip .
the question is:
 is it gas/air  or a void caused by vacuum?   

air or gas would have to be released by chemicals in the glass formula(sweepers or oxidizers ) usually those burn off as you melt/cook and fine the glass.

normally we would expect bubbles to be roundish  in shape .
since the "bubble" in the drop has a flat and pointed edges really doesn't
mean its not air or positive pressure , just that the fluid is is not liquid ( hot in this case) as it needs to be for the air to form the round bubbles we see in
other fluids like soda.

since the outside surface has stopped moving and the inside is still
yellow/orange hot  it contracts drawing itself to the already cold & not moving
 outside surface pulling itself apart and forming  voids  & creating a vacuum.

Anyway i think  its a vacuum .

Nope. You've got it backwards, there's a huge amount of surface COMPRESSION on these, that's why you can't break them. When you scratch normal glass and then put stress on it, the scratch turns into a crack and the glass breaks. Since the surface is under compression, the nicks and scratches won't grow and the glass won't break unless you make a deep enough break to get to the tension-filled core. Look at the vid around 1:45 and you can see them trying (and succeeding) to scratch the drop.

This is how tempered glass works, but it's oriented differently. Let's talk in X Y and Z terms: X is width, Y is height, and Z is depth. The tensile stress is on the pane in the Z axis, making it hard to break on the broad, flat side. But if you tap the edge of a pane of tempered glass applying stress on the X or Y axis, the whole thing will shatter. This is why your smartphone screen doesn't usually crack just at the edge when you drop it, but spider-webs all the way across the screen.

You should be able to make a similar material in almost any shape, but for it to behave the same way you need to cool the entire piece of glass at the same time.  The way the process works is that the outside cools quickest and hardens, and as the interior cools it pulls the on the outside.  This holds the outside in a state of compressive stress that is very tough and hard to break, which is why you can hit it with a hammer.

Spoke to two material physicists about this. They both said that the sphere created would in fact be harder than with a tail. BUT due to the immense tension it is under it would be quite unstable. Glass is already quite brittle, even more so in this situation so does not deform under stress but instead cracks. So if you were to hit it with a hammer the tiniest deformation would propagate micro-cracks. Under such high tension these would be enough to set off the chain. So not very indestructible.

That's actually a misconception, the reason the glass is thicker at the bottom is the way its made. It's typically found in older glass because of less-accurate manufacturing back then, NOT liquidation over time. Because of this you can see panes of glass made 1 year apart that are completely different.

I heard that glass is actually not a solid, but actually a very VERY viscous fluid.  A pane of glass, when left for a very long time in a vertical position, will gradually become thinner at the top and thicker at the bottom. That's my conceptual/mathematical interpretation of the drop, I'm sure there's more to it.  I think the reason the velocity is so high is due to that rapid change in temperature and the fact that the outside of the drop and the inside of the drop change at different rates causing a lot of tension.

Fair enough. I have limited experience in physics but here's my take on what determines the fracture velocity.  The potential energy equation shown at 4:48 is a function of Young's Modulus (elasticity parameter), the cross sectional area and the change in length (strain). The amount of strain is a function of the thermal expansion coefficient and and change in temperature (3:32). These determine the amount of potential energy and when the drop is fractured it is then released as kinetic energy.

You would be basing that on the speed of sound through air but sound travels after different speeds through different substances. The speed of sound through glass is 13000 ft/s or 2.46 miles/s which is what I was basing my assumption on. Check out the website Engineering ToolBox for the speed of sound in some common solids.
It's actually about 5 times the speed of sound.  The speed of sound is approximately 0.211 miles/sec.  The fracture velocity here is approximately 1.03 miles/sec.

The comment below explains why the Fracture Front speed is only around 1600 m/sec because as the cracks split they are forming new surfaces which is taking energy and slowing the speed of the crack propagation.

This is one excellent video.  To be able to see the fracture front moving in the glass is great.  A shock wave actually travels through at about 3300 m/sec (the Ralaigh Wave Speed), but as the fracture front accelerates to follow the shock wave when it gets to about 50% of the Ralaigh speed the cracks bifocate. Then because of the tension stress in the glass they accelerate and bifocate again.
In normal tempered glass the stress is less, the acceleration slower and the break pattern is bigger.

A car windshield is tempered, which is a type of heat treatment. It is somewhat similar to the prince rupert drops but not exactly. Tempered glass like a windshield has a designated shape which is cut and perfected before tempering (putting it in an oven) and then being quenched. Yes automotive glass is made the same way.  It's called tempered or safety glass.  As others have pointed out, the front windshield also gets layers of plastic laminate in addition, to prevent the small shards of glass from flying around when it's shattered.

A similar concept is used to strengthen concrete, and occasionally used with metal components like cables and bolts.  Search wiki for pretensioned concrete.

This is certainly true of the windshield of the car, however the side windows are not made like this. To answer the original question, even side windows do not have the properties of a Prince Rupert's Drop. If you break the glass of a car, it may shatter like normal glass - essentially hundreds of thousands of cracks running along and through the glass until it can no longer support its own weight and falls in pieces - but may also just 'spiderweb', where it maintains some structural integrity.

Additionally, cars' window are made of laminated glass - that is, a sandwich of glass and plastic. That way, when it breaks, the tiny glass pieces won't fly all over the place like the Prince Rupert drop did but will mostly stay glued on the plastic part. 
That way, you can avoid some nasty injuries due to the flying shards.

Well when you hit it with a larger surface area object there is more area for the window to give and take in energy, so it's able to withstand it. That one has more to do with force pressure (or whatever its called).  An object with larger surface area on a given face has its pressure dispersed over an area.  Thus a hammer's flat face won't break automobile window glass.  In the case of something like coins in a plastic bag or an emergency hammer that is pointed, the area of force is condensed into a much smaller area, thus applying a lot more pressure on that point and causing the glass to break.  I hope that answers your question. :)

What you're doing when you use the pin at the end of the hammer is creating a very small surface area. This allows the force to be concentrated at an extremely small point and therefore you get a higher psi. It's like if someone stepped on your foot with a tennis shoe vs if they stepped on your foot with a high heeled shoe, the high heel would hurt much more because the force is concentrated.

That's correct! The process is often referred to as "quenching" and is the exact process used to turn steel into martensite, which is its hardest crystal phase. There's another, related process called "tempering," which is a heat treatment that relieves some of the internal stresses (similar to the ones that shatter this drop!) and toughens the material by reducing its brittleness. You can temper glass too! The process is a little different though.

A lovely question! If you look up martensite steel, you'll find that it's steel that's produced by a very similar process as the one used for Prince Rupert's Drops - just not in drop form. It's a common method for making a very hard allotrope of steel, and it occurs due to very similar underlying physics. You probably won't get the same powdery shattering behavior though, due to the ductility of steel, though martensite is vulnerable to shattering from strong impacts.

I've made bunch of these drops with very small tails. The key is to use a tall vessel of water and to strongly heat up the stretching molten tail as the drop falls down to make it very thin or even break. When the drop solidifies in water (some of them will burst on their own), you can further reduce the tail by melting it with a blowtorch. It has to be done carefully. After that, the tip of the tail, now a tiny bead, won't be susceptible to chain reaction. The drop is still incredibly strong.

No way man you've got this.  The most difficult equation in the video is an integral.  Integrals are simply put the "area under the curve".  Basically you draw the function (squiggly line defined by the equation to the right of the big "S" looking thing) and then sum up all the area between the line and zero.  Pretty easy huh?

The maths was really easy, but the units were really unusual. All he did was take the distance, a few centimetres and divide it by a stupidly small unit of time, then average it. The same as say a runner going 100m in 12s would mean they did 8.33 meters per second.

It depends on how much you heat it.  Short answer, if you take it up to about 1000 F and keep it there for several hours, the glass doesn't quite melt but there is enough molecular motion in it that the internal stresses are slowly removed.  This process is called annealing and is used in pretty much all high temperature forming (glass, metal, etc) to remove dangerous internal stresses.
